required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Facilitate the Transition From Passive Feeding to Active Feeding in Preterm Infants Through Early Play
clinical_study.official_title: Facilitate the Transition From Passive Feeding to Active Feeding in Preterm Infants Through Early Play

brief_summary.textblock: The approach described here is based both on theoretical concepts and on the work of several teams of researchers. By positioning the baby and the appropriate adult, a speech bath, a sustained look and an expressive face, it is hypothesized that this early communication exercise will significantly improve the transition from passive feeding, active feeding of the premature child, from a qualitative and quantitative point of view.

primary_outcome.measure: age at the stoppage of enteral nutrition

secondary_outcome.description: Duration of the feeding in case of early game play
Evaluate the quantities drunk in case of early game play
Duration of the the newborn's waking state at the time of suckling

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual analogic scale for Satisfaction from 0 to 10
secondary_outcome.description: Assessing the satisfaction of the ALIJEU practice for the mother and the care team

arm_group.description: patient who can benefit from the ALIJEU for certain meals
patient who did not benefit from the ALIJEU

intervention.description: The intervention concerns the passage from the passive feed (gastric tube) to the active feed (breast, feeding bottle). We propose to set up a pleasant moment just before his meal. This is a practical exercise of a few minutes. The aim of this special moment is to facilitate child-adult exchanges, improve active food intake and reduce the length of hospital stay.

study_pop.textblock: Premate newborn with an age inferior to 32 weeks of amenorrhea at birth

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age of child at birth: <32 WA justified by the greater prevalence of oral disorders in these children.
- Age of the child at the start of the study: 35 WA, ie at the beginning of the establishment of active feeding within the unit.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Children with oral malformations
- Contra-indication to the realization to the ALIJEU (infection in progress, hemodynamic instability, etc.)
- Medical contraindications to oral diet
